questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with a recent type B aortic dissection presents with abdominal pain and lower limb ischemia with diminished femoral and popliteal pulses. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Repair the descending aorta

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Enalaprilat: Although used for blood pressure control, it doesn't address the underlying issue of malperfusion.
  • • Option A. Enalaprilat:
  • • Option B. Increasing nitroprusside: May help with blood pressure control but doesn't solve the urgent need for revascularization.
  • • Option B. Increasing nitroprusside:
  • • Option D. Switching to amlodipine: Not appropriate in an acute setting requiring immediate intervention.
  • • Option D. Switching to amlodipine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the signs of complicated type B aortic dissection (malperfusion syndromes) and the need for immediate surgical/endovascular repair.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with Marfan syndrome has an ascending aortic diameter of 4.3 cm, which has increased by 0.6 cm in the past year. Her mother had an aortic dissection. She is considering pregnancy. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Aortic repair before pregnancy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Atorvastatin: Statins are not indicated for aortic disease management in this context and are contraindicated in pregnancy.
  • • Option A. Atorvastatin:
  • • Option B. Losartan: Contraindicated in pregnancy due to fetal toxicity.
  • • Option B. Losartan:
  • • Option D. Proceeding with pregnancy without aortic repair would be dangerous due to the high risk of dissection.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with Marfan syndrome have an increased risk for pregnancy-related aortic dissection and rupture; aortic repair surgery is recommended before conception to reduce this risk in those with an ascending aortic diameter greater than 4.0 cm and who have risk factors for aortic dissection.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man with acute chest pain. ECG shows multifocal ST depressions. His BP is 170/100 mm Hg on the right arm and 140/90 mm Hg in the left arm. He also has a diastolic murmur at the left sternal border. What is the most appropriate diagnostic test?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Coronary angiography: Relatively contraindicated in suspected aortic dissection.
  • • Option A. Coronary angiography:
  • • Option B. Invasive aortography: Less commonly used compared to CTA for diagnosis.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. MRA: Time consuming and unnecessary in an emergency like in this case.
  • • Option C. MRA:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with suspected aortic dissection, perform TTE and CT angiography promptly for diagnosis and to guide management.

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman with extensive cardiovascular disease and poorly controlled hypertension is evaluated for acute-onset ripping chest pain that radiates to her back. Chest radiograph is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The most likely diagnosis is acute aortic dissection. This patient's chest radiograph shows a widened superior mediastinum and a right pleural effusion consistent with aortic dissection, although these findings are not diagnostic. The diagnosis of aortic dissection can be established with transesophageal echocardiography, CT angiography, or MR angiography, all of which have similar sensitivity and specificity for acute thoracic aortic disease. Because of its wide availability and short image acquisition time, CT angiography has become the primary diagnostic test for acute thoracic aortic disease.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man with peripheral artery disease (PAD) and persistent claudication despite exercise and optimal medical therapy (aspirin, statin, enalapril). What is the most appropriate additional treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Clopidogrel : Dual antiplatelet therapy is not routinely recommended for PAD.
  • • Option B. Clopidogrel
  • • Option C. Evolocumab : PCSK9 inhibitors are for patients with high LDL cholesterol despite statin therapy.
  • • Option C. Evolocumab
  • • Option D. Pentoxifylline : Not proven effective for claudication.
  • • Option D. Pentoxifylline

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ In patients with peripheral artery disease and intermittent claudication, cilostazol is recommended to improve limb symptoms in addition to smoking cessation, aspirin, statin therapy, and supervised exercise.
  • ➤ Cilostazol is contraindicated in patients with heart failure.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with acute chest pain for the last 3 hours. Aspirin and clopidogrel was given in the ambulance. ECG is taken in ER and shown below. What is the next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Reteplase : This is a thrombolytic agent used in STEMI and not in NSTE-ACS.
  • • Option A. Reteplase
  • • Option B. Tirofiban : GpIIb/IIIa inhibitor used primarily during PCI under special circumstances.
  • • Option B. Tirofiban
  • • Option D. Emergent Coronary angiography : While angiography is crucial to confirm the diagnosis and guide further management, immediate anticoagulation with enoxaparin should be initiated first. In this patient with ST depression (a high risk factor), URGENT coronary angiography is optimal (< 24h) rather than immediate (< 2h).
  • • Option D. Emergent Coronary angiography

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with suspected NSTE-ACS, early administration of enoxaparin is crucial to prevent further thrombus formation while awaiting coronary angiography.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man with exertional chest pain and a positive stress test undergoes angiography revealing complex multivessel coronary artery disease (CAD) involving the left main. He has a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 42%. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Medical therapy : Insufficient for complex CAD and reduced LVEF, carries a higher risk of adverse events.
  • • Option B. Medical therapy
  • • Option C. Viability testing : Not necessary before revascularization in this scenario.
  • • Option C. Viability testing
  • • Option D. PCI : Less favorable than CABG for complex multivessel disease, especially with left main involvement.
  • • Option D. PCI

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ In patients with multivessel coronary artery disease, coronary artery bypass grafting is associated with enhanced survival compared with medical therapy alone.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease presents with acute decompensated heart failure. He is dyspneic at rest and has bibasilar crackles on lung auscultation. Which of the following medications is NOT appropriate for initial
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Furosemide : Loop diuretic, cornerstone of therapy in ADHF to reduce fluid overload.
  • • Option A. Furosemide
  • • Option B. Nitroglycerin : Vasodilator, used to reduce preload and afterload, improving cardiac function in ADHF.
  • • Option B. Nitroglycerin
  • • Option D. CPAP : Non-invasive ventilation, often used in ADHF to improve oxygenation and decrease the work of breathing.
  • • Option D. CPAP

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (like verapamil) are C/I in acute decompensated heart failure due to their negative inotropic effects

questions.text: A 57-year-old man with stable angina and aspirin allergy is undergoing lifestyle counseling and antianginal therapy. What is the most appropriate cardioprotective treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Low-dose aspirin : Contraindicated due to aspirin allergy.
  • • Option B. Low-dose aspirin
  • • Option C. Prasugrel and Option D. Ticagrelor : More potent antiplatelet agents, typically used in acute coronary syndrome or after PCI, not as monotherapy for stable angina.
  • • Option C. Prasugrel
  • • Option
  • • D. Ticagrelor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ All patients with stable ischemic heart disease should receive guideline-directed therapies consisting of lifestyle modification, cardioprotective therapy, and antianginal medication. Patients with stable ischemic heart disease should receive antiplatelet therapy (low-dose aspirin or clopidogrel in aspirin-intolerant patients) for secondary prevention of cardiovascular events.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with decompensated heart failure is hospitalized and treated with a maximal dose of IV furosemide. He has minimal urine output and persistent signs of volume overload. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Add intravenous milrinone: Milrinone is an inotrope used to improve cardiac contractility. While it may help with cardiac output, it doesn't directly address the volume overload and can worsen renal function.
  • • Option A. Add intravenous milrinone:
  • • Option B. Add intravenous nitroglycerin: Nitroglycerin is a vasodilator that can reduce preload and afterload, but it's not the primary treatment for volume overload when diuretics fail.
  • • Option B. Add intravenous nitroglycerin:
  • • Option C. Increase furosemide: The patient is already on the maximal dose of furosemide, so further increases would not be effective and could lead to adverse effects.
  • • Option C. Increase furosemide:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ In patients with ADHF who are unresponsive to maximal diuretic therapy, CVVH is a crucial intervention to manage volume overload and prevent further complications.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman 3 months postpartum presents with recurrent exertional chest pain. Cardiac catheterization shows normal coronary arteries, and cardiac MRI reveals diffuse perfusion abnormalities. What is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Coronary vasospasm : This would cause transient ST-elevation on ECG.
  • • Option A. Coronary vasospasm
  • • Option C. Peripartum cardiomyopathy : Presents with heart failure symptoms, not typically isolated chest pain.
  • • Option C. Peripartum cardiomyopathy
  • • Option D. Spontaneous coronary artery dissection : More common in the peripartum period but would typically have abnormal coronary angiography findings.
  • • Option D. Spontaneous coronary artery dissection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Consider microvascular dysfunction as a potential cause of angina in women with normal coronary arteries on angiography.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with diabetes mellitus received a drug-eluting stent for non-ST elevation acute coronary syndrome (NSTE-ACS). She was started on dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with aspirin and clopidogrel. What is the recommended minimum duration of her antiplatelet therapy?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. 1 month: This duration is too short and would significantly increase the risk of stent thrombosis.
  • • Option A. 1 month:
  • • Option B. 3 months: While some studies suggest shorter durations may be safe in select patients, the standard recommendation for patients with diabetes is 12 months.
  • • Option B. 3 months:
  • • Option C. 6 months: This is the minimum duration for patients without diabetes who have received a drug-eluting stent for ACS.
  • • Option
  • • C. 6 months:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Understand the recommended duration of dual antiplatelet therapy in patients with diabetes who have undergone percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with drug-eluting stents for acute coronary syndrome.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man with persistent angina despite maximally tolerated antianginal therapy. He has orthostatic hypotension and current BP and PR are 100/60 mm Hg and 54/min respectively. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Addition of Clopidogrel : Not indicated for stable angina without recent revascularization.
  • • Option A. Addition of Clopidogrel
  • • Option B. Addition of Isosorbide mononitrate : Adding more antianginal medication may not be helpful if the patient is already on maximally tolerated doses. Addition of nitrate in this patient may worsen orthostatic hypotension.
  • • Option B. Addition of Isosorbide mononitrate
  • • Option D. Exercise echocardiography : May provide prognostic information but doesn't identify lesions for revascularization.
  • • Option D. Exercise echocardiography

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ In the setting of persistent symptoms despite maximally tolerated medical therapy, invasive imaging for revascularization assessment is appropriate to improve symptom status and quality of life.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a 6.1 cm abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) detected on routine USG screening. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Abdominal aortography : Invasive and less commonly used for AAA evaluation.
  • • Option A. Abdominal aortography
  • • Option B. ACE inhibitor therapy : Doesn't address the need for repair of a large AAA.
  • • Option B. ACE inhibitor therapy
  • • Option D. Open AAA repair : Premature before confirming the location and suitability for repair with CTA.
  • • Option D. Open AAA repair

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends one-time screening with duplex ultrasonography in all men aged 65 to 75 years who have smoked at least 100 cigarettes in their lifetime and selective screening in men in this age group who have never smoked.
  • ➤ CT angiography or magnetic resonance angiography is the imaging procedure of choice to identify the exact location of an abdominal aneurysm and plan operative repair.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man with Alzheimer's disease, on donepezil, presents with somnolence, hypotension (70/40 mmHg), and sinus bradycardia (30/min). What is the next treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Amiodarone : Antiarrhythmic drug, not indicated for bradycardia.
  • • Option A. Amiodarone
  • • Option B. Chest compressions : Not indicated if the patient has a pulse.
  • • Option B. Chest compressions
  • • Option D. Isoproterenol : Second-line chronotropic agent, considered if atropine is ineffective.
  • • Option D. Isoproterenol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ The treatment of hemodynamically unstable bradycardia with a pulse is intravenous atropine.
  • ➤ The most common extrinsic cause of sinus bradycardia is medication use (β-blockers, donepezil, neostigmine, pyridostigmine).

questions.text: A 75-year-old man with a history of atrial fibrillation, diabetes, and peripheral artery disease presents with acute left leg pain, absent pulses, and cold, mottled skin. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Angiography : Essential for diagnosis and planning revascularization, but anticoagulation should be started first.
  • • Option A. Angiography
  • • Option B. Apixaban : Oral anticoagulant, not appropriate in the acute setting of ALI.
  • • Option B. Apixaban
  • • Option D. Venous duplex ultrasonography : Not indicated for ALI, which is an arterial problem.
  • • Option D. Venous duplex ultrasonography

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Treat acute limb ischemia with anticoagulation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with no medical history presents with frequent, bothersome palpitations that subside with exercise and in the nights. ECG is shown. Echo and baseline lab tests including CBC and TFT are normal. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Amiodarone : Antiarrhythmic drug with potential toxicity, not first-line for simple PVCs.
  • • Option A. Amiodarone
  • • Option B. Exercise ECG : Not helpful for diagnosing PVCs.
  • • Option B. Exercise ECG
  • • Option D. Reassurance : Not sufficient for bothersome symptoms.
  • • Option D. Reassurance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Beta-blockers are the first-line treatment for symptomatic PVCs in patients without structural heart disease.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man with a history of coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) presents with worsening exertional chest pain. He is on aspirin, metoprolol, sublingual nitroglycerin, and rosuvastatin. ECG shows LBBB. Which is the most appropriate test?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Dobutamine echocardiography : Not ideal due to the presence of LBBB, which can hinder image interpretation.
  • • Option A. Dobutamine echocardiography
  • • Option B. Exercise ECG : LBBB limits the interpretability of exercise ECG for ischemia.
  • • Option B. Exercise ECG
  • • Option C. Exercise SPECT : Exercise increases heart rate which can worsen artefacts due to LBBB.
  • • Option C. Exercise SPECT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ In the evaluation of patients with chest pain, vasodilator myocardial perfusion imaging with adenosine, regadenoson, or dipyridamole minimizes septal abnormalities frequently seen with exercise or dobutamine myocardial perfusion imaging.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with recurrent chest pain and elevated troponin. ECG is shown. remains in pain despite aspirin, clopidogrel, heparin, and nitroglycerin. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Echocardiography : May be helpful, but not the immediate priority.
  • • Option A. Echocardiography
  • • Option B. Eplerenone : Indicated in certain post-MI patients, but not the immediate priority for refractory angina.
  • • Option B. Eplerenone
  • • Option C. Oxygen per nasal cannula : Indicated only if the patient is hypoxic.
  • • Option C. Oxygen per nasal cannula

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Urgent or immediate diagnostic angiography with intent to perform revascularization is indicated in patients with NSTE-ACS who have refractory angina or hemodynamic or electrical instability.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with a history of radiation therapy for Hodgkin lymphoma presents with exertional dyspnea and a burning sensation in her throat. She has no history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, or diabetes and she is a non-smoker. Physical examination and chest X-ray are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Aortic stenosis : Valvular diseases are possible after radiation but less likely given the normal physical exam.
  • • Option A. Aortic stenosis
  • • Option B . Constrictive pericarditis and Option D . Restrictive cardiomyopathy : These can occur after radiation but typically present with additional signs like elevated JVP, edema, or diastolic dysfunction.
  • • Option B
  • • Constrictive pericarditis
  • • Option
  • • D
  • • Restrictive cardiomyopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Cancer survivors who received chest radiotherapy are at risk for the late development of cardiovascular complications, including pericardial constriction, valvular heart disease, restrictive cardiomyopathy, and coronary artery disease.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with type 2 diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and aortofemoral bypass surgery 2 years ago has an HbA1c of 7.1%. His current medications are metformin, atenolol, ramipril, amlodipine, aspirin, rivaroxaban, and atorvastatin. Which medication is most appropriate to add for cardiovascular risk reduction?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Clopidogrel : Patient is already on rivaroxaban and aspirin. Addition of clopidogrel would not provide any additional benefit and only increase the bleeding risk.
  • • Option A. Clopidogrel
  • • Option C. Niacin : No longer recommended for routine use due to lack of benefit and side effects.
  • • Option C. Niacin
  • • Option D. Pramlintide : Amylin analog used for glycemic control, no proven cardiovascular benefit.
  • • Option D. Pramlintide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ In patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus, sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 inhibitors and glucagon-like peptide 1 receptor agonists are associated with reduced rates of adverse cardiovascular events, including stroke, myocardial infarction, and cardiovascular death, compared with placebo.

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman 6-month history of right shoulder pain on exertion and it is relieved by rest. Her ECG shows LBBB. She has no known comorbidities and not on any regular medications. What is the most appropriate test?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Coronary angiography : Not the initial test for stable angina. It should be reserved for patients with a high pretest likelihood of CAD and unstable symptoms, or for those in whom optimal medical therapy has been ineffective.
  • • Option A. Coronary angiography
  • • Option B. Exercise ECG : LBBB limits interpretation of ECG changes.
  • • Option B. Exercise ECG
  • • Option D. No further testing: Inappropriate as the patient has exertional chest pain.
  • • Option D. No further testing:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ S tress testing with imaging is indicated in patients with an inability to exercise, baseline ECG abnormalities that limit interpretation of the exercise ECG, or indeterminate findings on the exercise ECG.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man with type 2 diabetes and a history of stroke is on aspirin, metformin, olmesartan, and rosuvastatin. His LDL-C is 66 mg/dL, HDL-C is 28 mg/dL and HbA1c is 6.8%. What additional medication should be considered for CV risk reduction?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Ezetimibe : Not indicated as LDL cholesterol is already well-controlled.
  • • Option B. Ezetimibe
  • • Option C. Niacin : Can increase HDL but no longer recommended for routine use due to lack of benefit and side effects.
  • • Option C. Niacin
  • • Option D. No changes in management : Inadequate as SGLT2 inhibitors provide additional CV benefit.
  • • Option D. No changes in management

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Consider adding SGLT2 inhibitors to the treatment regimen for patients with type 2 diabetes and established ASCVD to reduce CV risk.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presents with severe chest pain and diaphoresis. His ECG is shown below. His cardiac troponins were elevated and he was started on aspirin, ticagrelor and UFH. He experiences recurrent chest pain, hypotension and hence coronary angiogram was done which was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Coronary plaque rupture : Would be visible on angiography.
  • • Option A. Coronary plaque rupture
  • • Option C. Pulmonary embolism : Usually presents with pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea.
  • • Option C. Pulmonary embolism
  • • Option D. Stress cardiomyopathy : More common in elderly women and usually triggered by stress.
  • • Option D. Stress cardiomyopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Coronary vasospasm can mimic ACS and may present with recurrent chest pain, ECG changes, and even troponin elevation, despite normal coronary arteries.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with CAD and diabetes mellitus experiences worsening angina. He is currently on ramipril, diltiazem, metformin, atorvastatin and isosorbide mononitrate twice daily. What is the most appropriate management?

options.label: C
options.text: Reduce isosorbide mononitrate dosage to once daily

questions.correct_answer: C. Reduce isosorbide mononitrate dosage to once daily
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Adding amlodipine : Not the first-line option when nitrate tolerance is suspected.
  • • Option A. Adding amlodipine
  • • Option B. Decreasing lisinopril : Not indicated as blood pressure is controlled.
  • • Option B. Decreasing lisinopril
  • • Option D. Repeat coronary angiography : Not necessary unless there is a suspicion of new coronary lesions or progression of existing ones.
  • • Option D. Repeat coronary angiography

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Long-acting nitrates provide a constant level of vasodilation and symptom relief throughout the day, but a nitrate-free interval is required to avoid tolerance.

questions.text: An 80-year-old man with diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia presents with a 6-week history of resting foot pain and a non-healing ulcer. His ankle-brachial index (ABI) is 0.44 on the right and 0.62 on the left. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. CT angiography : Can be helpful but is not the first step for patients with CLTI.
  • • Option A. CT angiography
  • • Option B. Hyperbaric oxygen treatment : Not a primary treatment for CLTI, but may be adjunctive.
  • • Option B. Hyperbaric oxygen treatment
  • • Option D. Primary amputation : Not the initial approach in patients with potentially salvageable limbs.
  • • Option D. Primary amputation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI) is characterized by more than 2 weeks of ischemic rest pain, nonhealing wound/ulcers, or gangrene in one or both legs that is attributable to objectively proven peripheral artery disease.
  • ➤ In patients with CLTI, immediate invasive angiography with endovascular revascularization is often the most effective strategy to preserve tissue viability.

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman with chest pain over 24 hours and it is worsening despite multiple doses of NTG. She is known case of hypertension and dyslipidaemia and on enalapril and rosuvastatin. Her ECG 3 months ago was normal and her current ECG in the ER is shown. Her initial troponin is normal. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Coronary artery calcium scoring : No use in patients who are already receiving statins and not helpful in the acute setting.
  • • Option A. Coronary artery calcium scoring
  • • Option B. Coronary CT angiography : May be considered, but invasive angiography is preferred for immediate diagnosis and potential intervention.
  • • Option B. Coronary CT angiography
  • • Option D. Exercise ECG : C/I in the context of acute/ongoing ischemia.
  • • Option D. Exercise ECG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Invasive coronary angiography is the preferred diagnostic test in patients with refractory angina to assess coronary anatomy and guide potential revascularization.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with inferior STEMI and he is successfully treated with PCI. He has a history of paroxysmal AF and was taking flecainide. He was also started on rivaroxaban, metoprolol, and ramipril post PCI. He is currently asymptomatic and now planned for discharge from the hospital. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Ambulatory ECG monitoring : Helpful for assessing AF burden but doesn't address the contraindication of flecainide.
  • • Option A. Ambulatory ECG monitoring
  • • Option C. Discontinue metoprolol : Not ideal as it's essential for managing ischemic heart disease.
  • • Option C. Discontinue metoprolol
  • • Option D. Exercise stress testing : Not recommended immediately post-MI, especially with existing conduction abnormalities.
  • • Option D. Exercise stress testing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Class IC antiarrhythmics like flecainide are C/I in patients with ischemic heart disease due to an increased risk of ventricular arrhythmias and death.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with stable angina has persistent symptoms despite maximally tolerated medical therapy. Coronary Angiogram shows 70% proximal RCA stenosis and 80% obtuse marginal artery stenosis. What benefit can the patient expect from CABG?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Discontinuation of medications : Not recommended after CABG.
  • • Option A. Discontinuation of medications
  • • Option C. Increased survival : Less likely in this patient without multivessel or left main disease.
  • • Option C. Increased survival
  • • Option D. Reduced risk of MI : Possible, but not the primary goal in this case.
  • • Option D. Reduced risk of MI

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Primary goal of revascularization instable angina is symptom relief.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman is evaluated for atypical chest pain. Exercise stress testing is performed. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Ans.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man with a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia has chronic stable angina. Which of the following medications have been shown to reduce mortality and risk of myocardial infarction (MI)?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Ranolazine: Ranolazine is a newer anti-anginal medication that works by reducing myocardial oxygen demand. While it is effective in relieving angina symptoms, it has not been shown to reduce mortality or MI risk.
  • • Option A. Ranolazine:
  • • Option B. β-Blockers: Beta-blockers are first-line therapy for chronic stable angina. They reduce myocardial oxygen demand by decreasing heart rate and contractility. While they are effective in controlling angina symptoms and improving exercise tolerance, their impact on mortality is less clear.
  • • Option B. β-Blockers:
  • • Option D. Nitrates: Nitrates are potent vasodilators that improve myocardial blood flow and reduce angina symptoms. They are primarily used for symptom relief and do not have a significant impact on mortality or MI risk.
  • • Option D. Nitrates:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Aspirin reduces mortality and MI risk in patients with chronic stable angina.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man with a history of hypertension and CAD presents with recurrent atrial flutter. He is on dabigatran, metoprolol, ramipril, aspirin, and atorvastatin. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Amiodarone : Antiarrhythmic drug with potential for toxicity, not the first-line treatment.
  • • Option A. Amiodarone
  • • Option B. Cardiac catheterization : Not needed for treating atrial flutter at this point.
  • • Option B. Cardiac catheterization
  • • Option C. Cardioversion : May provide temporary relief but is not definitive treatment in this case where the patient is experiencing recurrence.
  • • Option C. Cardioversion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Catheter ablation is the best treatment for recurrent typical atrial flutter.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman with ischemic cardiomyopathy presents with progressive dyspnea, edema and confusion. Her medications include low-dose aspirin, furosemide, carvedilol, ramipril, digoxin, and spironolactone. Her BP is 84/52 mm Hg, PR is 118/min, RR is 28/min and SpO2 is 95 in room air. Her reports are shown below. ALT - 172 U/L, AST - 163 U/L, S. Creatinine - 2.9 mg/dL , S. K - 4.7 mEq/L, S. Na - 132 mEq/L & S. Digoxin - 0.3 ng/mL. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Increase carvedilol : Beta-blockers are contraindicated in cardiogenic shock.
  • • Option A. Increase carvedilol
  • • Option B. Increase digoxin : Not effective in cardiogenic shock and potentially harmful with AKI.
  • • Option B. Increase digoxin
  • • Option C. Increase lisinopril : Afterload reduction may be considered later, but inotropic support is the priority in this patient with cardiogenic shock.
  • • Option C. Increase lisinopril

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ In patients with cardiogenic shock, inotropes such as Noradrenaline, dobutamine or milrinone may be considered to improve cardiac function.

questions.text: A 75-year-old asymptomatic woman with CAD, diabetes and hypertension presents with palpitations. ECG shows AF. She is on metoprolol, telmisartan, aspirin, and atorvastatin. What is the most appropriate treatment?

options.label: C
options.text: Discontinue aspirin and begin oral anticoagulation

questions.correct_answer: C. Discontinue aspirin and begin oral anticoagulation
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Adding clopidogrel : Not indicated, as the patient has no recent ACS or stent.
  • • Option A. Adding clopidogrel
  • • Option B. Adding oral anticoagulation without discontinuing aspirin : Increases bleeding risk.
  • • Option B. Adding oral anticoagulation without discontinuing aspirin
  • • Option D. No change in therapy : Inadequate as the patient needs anticoagulation for stroke prevention.
  • • Option D. No change in therapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ For most patients with high-risk atrial fibrillation and stable coronary artery disease, oral anticoagulation therapy without an antiplatelet agent is sufficient for prevention of both acute coronary syndromes and thromboembolism.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with a history of peripheral artery disease (PAD) presents with acute right leg pain. On examination, the right foot is cool and pedal pulses are absent. Sensation and muscle strength are normal. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Arterial duplex ultrasonography: While useful for diagnosing PAD, it is not the immediate priority in acute limb ischemia. Revascularization should be initiated before obtaining imaging studies.
  • • Option A. Arterial duplex ultrasonography:
  • • Option B. CT angiography: This can provide a detailed view of the arterial anatomy and identify the location of the occlusion, but it should not delay revascularization.
  • • Option B. CT angiography:
  • • Option C. Emergent right leg amputation: This is a last resort if revascularization fails or is not possible. Amputation should not be considered until all revascularization options have been exhausted.
  • • Option C. Emergent right leg amputation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Prompt initiation of anticoagulation with heparin in ALI to prevent further thrombus formation and limb loss.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with diabetes and PAD has a right foot ulcer and feeble pulses. Ankle Brachial Index (ABI) on the right is 1.65. What is the next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Exercise ABI : Not useful when resting ABI is uninterpretable.
  • • Option A. Exercise ABI
  • • Option B. Lower Extremity CT angiography : Helpful for planning revascularization, but TBI is the more appropriate initial test in this scenario.
  • • Option B. Lower Extremity CT angiography
  • • Option D. Venous duplex ultrasonography : Evaluates for venous disease, not arterial.
  • • Option D. Venous duplex ultrasonography

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Toe-brachial index (TBI) is useful in diagnosing PAD when ankle-brachial index (ABI) is uninterpretable due to non-compressible vessels.

questions.text: 52-year-old woman complains of chest tightness after walking for 2-3 km and relieved with rest. Her resting ECG is normal. She is known case of hypertension and dyslipidemia and currently taking ramipril and atorvastatin. What is the most appropriate diagnostic test?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Adenosine single-photon emission CT : Reserved for patients who cannot exercise or have uninterpretable ECGs.
  • • Option A. Adenosine single-photon emission CT
  • • Option B. Coronary artery calcium scoring : Used for risk stratification in asymptomatic patients especially to know the need for a statin. The patient is already on atorvastatin.
  • • Option B. Coronary artery calcium scoring
  • • Option D. Stress echocardiography : Can be considered if exercise ECG is inconclusive.
  • • Option D. Stress echocardiography

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Exercise ECG is the first-line test for evaluating suspected CAD in patients with typical angina and a normal resting ECG.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with ischemic cardiomyopathy (EF 20%) and NYHA class III heart failure is on maximally tolerated doses of ACE inhibitor, furosemide, and empagliflozin. ECG shows LBBB with a QRS duration of 130 ms. What is the most appropriate additional treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Add Ivabradine : Indicated only after maximally tolerated beta-blocker dose.
  • • Option B. Add Ivabradine
  • • Option D. CRT-D : Considered if LVEF remains ≤35%, QRS duration ≥150 ms, and NYHA class II-IV symptoms despite optimal medical therapy.
  • • Option D. CRT-D
  • • Option C. Add digoxin : Considered for primary prevention of sudden cardiac death in patients with LVEF ≤35% despite optimal medical therapy.
  • • Option C.
  • • Add digoxin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Initiate beta-blocker therapy in patients with HFrEF who are not already on it, as part of guideline-directed medical therapy.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman presents with acute type B aortic dissection involving the descending thoracic aorta with a maximal aortic diameter of 6.8 cm. Her BP is 173/99 mm Hg and PR is 90/min. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Immediate endovascular stenting: Endovascular stenting can be used to treat patients with descending aortic aneurysms; however, there is scant evidence to support this as an initial treatment option for aneurysm with dissection. After medical stabilization, thoracic endovascular aortic repair (TEVAR) with stent grafting can be used; typical indications include descending aortic aneurysm diameter greater than 6.0 cm, rapid growth (>0.5 cm/year), or end-organ damage. TEVAR has the advantage over surgical operation of lower morbidity and shorter hospital stay, although there may be complications, including stroke, spinal ischemia, and aortic graft endoleaks. This patient should be treated with stent implantation only after medical stabilization.
  • • Option A. Immediate endovascular stenting:
  • • Option B. Immediate open surgical repair: Open surgical repair of the descending aorta is not recommended in patients with uncomplicated type B aortic dissection because of high rates of morbidity (such as paraplegia) and mortality. This patient has no signs or symptoms of complications that would prompt immediate surgical repair.
  • • Option B. Immediate open surgical repair:
  • • Option D. Repeat CT angiography in 12 hours: Repeat CT angiography at 12 hours is not indicated unless the patient does not stabilize with medical therapy. Serial imaging (usually magnetic resonance angiography) is typically performed in asymptomatic patients at the time of discharge and then periodically in patients who do not have an indication for aneurysmal repair to screen for extension or recurrence of the dissection, aneurysm formation, and leakage.
  • • Option D. Repeat CT angiography in 12 hours:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Patients with uncomplicated type B aortic dissection may be initially treated with medical therapy, including β-blockers, sodium nitroprusside, and opioids.

questions.text: An 81-year-old woman had a drug-eluting stent (DES) for chronic stable angina 1 month ago. She is currently on aspirin and clopidogrel. She is a known case of hypertension, dyslipidaemia, CKD and peptic ulcer disease and was on medications for the same. She wants to minimize DAPT in view of her age and comorbidities. How long should she continue DAPT?

options.label: D
options.text: Discontinue clopidogrel and aspirin in 11 months

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Discontinuing clopidogrel in 1 month can be done in case of bare metal stents (BMS) and not DES.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option C. 12 months of DAPT is recommended in patient with ACS.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D . Aspirin should be continued indefinitely in patients with CAD.
  • • Option D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Dual antiplatelet therapy is recommended for at least 6 months after drug-eluting stent placement for treatment of stable angina.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with recent post-CABG (coronary artery bypass graft) status presents with chest pain. On arrival, his blood pressure is 60/30 mmHg with a heart rate of 30/min. The ECG shows a narrow complex arrhythmia. The patient has already received three boluses of IV atropine. While awaiting transcutaneous pacing, which of the following is the next appropriate step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Another bolus of atropine: As per ACLS guidelines, a maximum of three boluses of atropine are recommended for symptomatic bradycardia. Further doses are unlikely to be effective.
  • • Option A. Another bolus of atropine:
  • • Option B. IV Norepinephrine: While norepinephrine is a potent vasopressor, it can also worsen bradycardia due to its reflex bradycardia effect (baroreceptor response).
  • • Option B. IV Norepinephrine:
  • • Opion D. IV Dobutamine: Dobutamine primarily acts on beta-1 receptors, increasing heart rate and contractility, but it can also cause vasodilation (beta-2 effects), potentially worsening hypotension.
  • • Opion D. IV Dobutamine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Chronotropic drugs like dopamine can be tried while awaiting pacing in symptomatic bradycardia with hypotension, especially when atropine has been ineffective.

questions.text: Which of the following non-invasive tests has the best accuracy in detecting coronary stenosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. CMR perfusion have high sensitivity, but their specificity is not as high as Coronary CTA, meaning they might produce more false-positive results.
  • • Option A. CMR perfusion
  • • Option D. Exercise echocardiography and Option C. SPECT MPI have lower sensitivity and specificity than Coronary CTA, indicating a higher chance of both false negatives and false positives.
  • • Option D. Exercise echocardiography
  • • Option
  • • C. SPECT MPI

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Coronary CTA is a highly accurate non-invasive test for detecting coronary stenosis due to its excellent sensitivity and specificity. It is a valuable tool for diagnosing and evaluating CAD.

questions.text: Mr. Xavier, a 72-year-old retired judge, experiences increased fatigue during walking. His physical exam, vitals, baseline ECG and 2D Echo are normal. Exercise ECG shows a peak heart rate of 96 beats/min with no ST changes. What is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. HFpEF : Unlikely given the normal echocardiogram, especially the normal atrial size.
  • • Option B. HFpEF
  • • Option C. Lung disease : Unlikely given the normal chest X-ray and absence of respiratory symptoms.
  • • Option C. Lung disease
  • • Option D. Normal aging : While aging can cause some decline in exercise tolerance, this patient's significant fatigue suggests a pathological cause.
  • • Option D. Normal aging

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Predicted maximal HR ∼ 220-Age

questions.text: Mr. Venkatesh, a 40-year-old man with hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide and metoprolol, presents with fatigue. His physical exam is normal except for a heart rate of 40 beats/min. ECG shows sinus bradycardia. Lab tests, including thyroid function and hemoglobin, are normal. What is the most reasonable next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Dual chamber Pacemaker implantation : This may be indicated later if the bradycardia persists or is symptomatic after discontinuing the beta-blocker.
  • • Option A. Dual chamber Pacemaker implantation
  • • Option B. Exercise ECG test : This may be helpful to assess the chronotropic response, but the priority is to address the potential medication-induced bradycardia first.
  • • Option B. Exercise ECG test
  • • Option C. Start isoprenaline 10mg TID : This is a pure beta agonist with chronotropic effects and is not a first-line treatment for bradycardia.
  • • Option C. Start isoprenaline 10mg TID

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Beta blockers and calcium channel blockers increase sinus node recovery time and can cause severe sinus bradycardia in some individuals.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man with bacterial pneumonia experiences a sudden lightheadedness. His BP is stable, and the rhythm strip is shown. Which of the following is most likely to lead to sustained improvement in heart rate?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Adenosine 6 mg IV : Primarily used for supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) and may not be effective in FAT.
  • • Option A. Adenosine 6 mg IV
  • • Option B. Carotid body massage : A vagal maneuver that may temporarily slow the heart rate but is not a definitive treatment.
  • • Option B. Carotid body massage
  • • Option D. Valsalva maneuver : A vagal maneuver that may temporarily slow the heart rate but is not a definitive treatment.
  • • Option D. Valsalva maneuver

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Focal atrial tachycardia is not dependent on the AV node and beta-blockers or non-dihydropyridine CCBs are the preferred treatment options for rate control.

questions.text: You are called to the ER for a young patient in cardiac arrest during exercise. ECG showed bidirectional VT and it was cardioverted immediately. ECG post-cardioversion is normal. 2D Echo and cardiac MRI are also normal. Mutations in which protein are responsible for this?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Desmosomal proteins: Mutations in desmosomal proteins cause arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC), which is a structural heart disease.
  • • Option B. Desmosomal proteins:
  • • Option C. Potassium channel: Mutations in potassium channels can cause long QT syndrome. In this case resting ECG would have showed long QTc.
  • • Option C. Potassium channel:
  • • Option D. Sarcomere proteins: Mutations in sarcomere proteins cause hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), which would have resulted in structural heart disease.
  • • Option D. Sarcomere proteins:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Recognize bidirectional VT as a hallmark of CPVT, an inherited arrhythmia syndrome caused by mutations in the cardiac ryanodine receptor (RyR2).

questions.text: Mr. Vadivel, a 5-year post-heart transplant patient with no prior rejection episodes, presents with progressive exertional dyspnea and chest discomfort. He is on tacrolimus, mycophenolate mofetil, and low-dose prednisolone. 2D Echo shows normal LV function and no valvular abnormalities. What is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Antibody-mediated rejection : Rare this far out from transplant, especially without prior rejection.
  • • Option A. Antibody-mediated rejection
  • • Option B. Cellular rejection : Unlikely with normal LV function and no arrhythmias.
  • • Option B. Cellular rejection
  • • Option D. Endocarditis : Less likely without fever or new murmur.
  • • Option D. Endocarditis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Recognize that coronary artery disease is a major cause of late mortality in heart transplant recipients, even in the absence of typical risk factors or angina.

questions.text: Cardiac allograft vasculopathy (CAV) is different from atherosclerotic CAD. Which of the following regarding CAV is false?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option B. Minimal calcification: CAV lesions often have minimal calcification, particularly in the early stages, which can make them difficult to detect on standard coronary angiography.
  • • Option B. Minimal calcification:
  • • Option C. Poor collaterals: The development of collateral vessels is often impaired in CAV, making the heart more vulnerable to ischemia and infarction.
  • • Option C. Poor collaterals:
  • • Option d. Microvasculature affected: CAV can affect both the epicardial coronary arteries and the microvasculature, leading to diffuse myocardial dysfunction.
  • • Option
  • • d. Microvasculature affected:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ CAV is different from CAD and difficult to treat.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with severe chest pain. His ECG shows ST-segment depression and his initial troponin level is elevated. He is currently taking aspirin, amlodipine, simvastatin, and tadalafil. Which of the following medications should NOT be administered?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Clopidogrel : P2Y12 inhibitor, indicated in NSTEMI.
  • • Option A. Clopidogrel
  • • Option B. Heparin IV : Anticoagulation, indicated in NSTEMI.
  • • Option B. Heparin IV
  • • Option C. Metoprolol IV : Beta-blocker, indicated in NSTEMI unless contraindicated (e.g., heart failure).
  • • Option C. Metoprolol IV

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Be aware of the contraindication of nitroglycerin in patients taking phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors due to the risk of severe hypotension.

questions.text: You are seeing a 75-year-old man admitted for non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction. He has a history of CAD and takes daily aspirin. He's had multiple angina episodes in the past few days, has ST-segment depression on ECG, and elevated troponin. Which of the following details does NOT confer increased risk of poor outcomes?

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above confer increased risk.

questions.correct_answer: D. All of the above confer increased risk.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Two anginal episode in 24 hours : High risk indicating loss of ischemic preconditioning and an active/ongoing ischemia.
  • • Option A. Two anginal episode in 24 hours
  • • Option B. Age : Advanced age is the SINGLE most important risk factor in ACS.
  • • Option B. Age
  • • Option C. Daily aspirin use : While aspirin is cardioprotective, ACS despite use of aspirin indicates high thrombus burden and hence, high risk.
  • • Option C. Daily aspirin use

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ TIMI score for NSTE-ACS is important!

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman experiences recurrent chest pain with transient ST elevations during episodes. Angiography shows normal coronary arteries, but pain is worse during hyperventilation. Which of the following is NOT a reasonable treatment for her condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Amlodipine & Option D. Diltiazem (calcium channel blockers): These relax the smooth muscle in the coronary arteries, preventing or reversing vasospasm.
  • • Option A. Amlodipine & Option D. Diltiazem
  • • Option C. Long-acting oral nitrates: These medications help to dilate the coronary arteries and reduce the frequency of vasospastic episodes.
  • • Option C. Long-acting oral nitrates:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Aspirin is C/I in Prinzmetal's angina due to its potential to worsen vasospasm.

questions.text: Mr. Sengutuvel, a 57-year-old man with risk factors for CAD, presents with crushing chest pain, diaphoresis, and shortness of breath. Which diagnostic test will most rapidly guide therapeutic management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Coronary CT angiography : Coronary CT angiography is not warranted in a patient having active ischemic pain.
  • • Option B. Coronary CT angiography
  • • Option C. Echocardiogram : Can show wall motion abnormalities but cannot differentiate between STEMI and NSTEMI.
  • • Option C. Echocardiogram
  • • Option D. Serum troponin I level : A key biomarker for MI, but it takes time to elevate, and ECG is crucial for immediate decision-making.
  • • Option D. Serum troponin I level

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ In patients with suspected ACS, a 12-lead ECG is the most rapid and crucial test to guide immediate management decisions, especially regarding the need for urgent reperfusion therapy.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man with a history of smoking presents with progressive bilateral calf pain that worsens with walking and improves with rest. He has normal resting ankle-brachial index (ABI) values. What is the most appropriate next test?

options.label: D
options.text: Segmental lower extremity blood pressure testing

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Invasive angiography : Not the initial test, reserved for patients with severe PAD or when revascularization is planned.
  • • Option B. Invasive angiography
  • • Option C. MRA : Another option for anatomic imaging, but exercise ABI is a less invasive first step.
  • • Option C. MRA
  • • Option D. Segmental lower extremity blood pressure testing : Used to localize PAD, but not necessary as the initial test when the ABI is normal.
  • • Option D. Segmental lower extremity blood pressure testing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 25% of patients with typical claudication symptoms have a normal or borderline ankle-brachial index.
  • ➤ Exercise ABI testing is useful to evaluate for peripheral artery disease in patients with normal ABI values (>0.90 and ≤1.40) and high suspicion of PAD.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is evaluated one month after atherectomy and stenting of the right superficial femoral artery for severe claudication. He is now asymptomatic and on guideline-directed medical therapy (GDMT) for peripheral artery disease (PAD). Lab results show total cholesterol 120 mg/dL, LDL 50 mg/dL, and HDL 48 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate additional treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Cilostazol : Used to improve walking distance in patients with claudication, but not necessary for asymptomatic patients.
  • • Option A. Cilostazol
  • • Option B. Evolocumab : A PCSK9 inhibitor used to further lower LDL cholesterol in high-risk patients. Not indicated in this patient with well-controlled LDL.
  • • Option B. Evolocumab
  • • Option C. Ticagrelor : A more potent antiplatelet agent, not routinely recommended for PAD in addition to aspirin. May be added in high risk PAD (e.g., if associated CAD).
  • • Option C. Ticagrelor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Guideline-directed medical therapy for peripheral artery disease includes exercise; an antiplatelet agent; and aggressive management of atherosclerotic risk factors, including smoking, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and dyslipidemia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with hyperlipidemia, prediabetes, and a significant smoking history is seeking cardiovascular risk reduction. Which intervention is most likely to have the greatest impact on his risk?
questions.correct_answer: C. Smoking cessation counseling and varenicline
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Depression screening and treatment : Important, but smoking cessation has a more immediate and significant impact on cardiovascular risk.
  • • Option A. Depression screening and treatment
  • • Option B. Low-dose aspirin : Controversial and not routinely recommended for primary prevention in this scenario.
  • • Option B. Low-dose aspirin
  • • Option D. Weight loss : Beneficial for cardiovascular health but less impactful than smoking cessation.
  • • Option D. Weight loss

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Smoking cessation substantially reduces cardiovascular risk within 2 years, with risk returning to the level of a nonsmoker after ∼ 15 years.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man with a history of atrial fibrillation, diabetes, and peripheral artery disease presents with acute left leg pain, absent pulses, and cold, mottled skin. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Angiography: Essential for diagnosis and planning revascularization, but anticoagulation should be started first.
  • • Option A. Angiography:
  • • Option B. Apixaban : Oral anticoagulant, not appropriate in the acute setting of ALI.
  • • Option B. Apixaban
  • • Option D. Venous duplex ultrasonography : Not indicated for ALI, which is an arterial problem.
  • • Option D. Venous duplex ultrasonography

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Treat acute limb ischemia with anticoagulation.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man with peripheral artery disease (PAD) was prescribed atorvastatin. He has read in a newspaper that statins can cause muscle aches and stopped taking atorvastatin after he developed worsening leg pain upon walking. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Colestipol (bile acid resin): Not a first-line agent for PAD.
  • • Option B. Colestipol
  • • Option C. Ezetimibe (cholesterol absorption inhibitor): Monotherapy with ezetimibe is NOT a substitute for statin therapy. Can be used as an add on if LDL-C is not adequately reduced.
  • • Option C. Ezetimibe
  • • Option D. Icosapent ethyl (fish oil): Used for triglyceride lowering, which may be considered in addition to statins to lower CV risk (in patients with triglycerides of 135-499 mg/dL).
  • • Option D. Icosapent ethyl

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Peripheral artery disease is considered a clinical atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease.
  • ➤ Statin therapy is recommended for secondary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease in patients with peripheral artery disease.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a recent non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) and peripheral artery disease (PAD) is on dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT), an ACE inhibitor, a statin, and a beta-blocker. He is asymptomatic. His resting ankle-brachial index (ABI) is low bilaterally. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Exercise ABI testing : Indicated for symptomatic patients with normal or borderline resting ABI.
  • • Option A. Exercise ABI testing
  • • Option B. Lower extremity CT angiography : Considered if revascularization is planned.
  • • Option B. Lower extremity CT angiography
  • • Option C. Toe-brachial index testing : Used when ABI is unreliable due to non-compressible arteries.
  • • Option C. Toe-brachial index testing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ The American College of Cardiology recommends resting ankle-brachial index testing in patients with history or physical examination findings suggestive of peripheral artery disease.
  • ➤ Patients with both coronary artery disease and peripheral artery disease are at higher risk for major adverse cardiovascular events.
  • ➤ Also, avoid unnecessary testing in a patient with asymptomatic peripheral artery disease.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and CAD presents with a 3-month history of progressive left calf discomfort exacerbated by walking stairs but absent at rest. He is a smoker and he is currently on aspirin, rosuvastatin, metoprolol, and amlodipine. His left ABI is 0.68. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. CT angiography : While CT angiography is used for diagnosis and pre-procedural planning in PAD, it is not the first-line treatment for claudication.
  • • Option A. CT angiography
  • • Option B. Pentoxifylline : Not recommended for PAD treatment as it lacks evidence of benefit.
  • • Option B. Pentoxifylline
  • • Option C. Revascularization : Revascularization (either surgical or endovascular) may be considered if symptoms are refractory to exercise and medical therapy. However, it's not the initial step in management.
  • • Option C. Revascularization

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Supervised exercise training is the most effective initial treatment to increase walking distance for patients with intermittent claudication due to PAD.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman with peripheral artery disease (PAD) has persistent claudication despite supervised exercise and optimal medical therapy. Her current medications are aspirin, metformin, canagliflozin, cilostazol, atorvastatin, and olmesartan. CT angiogram reveals an 80% stenosis in the left iliac artery. What is the best treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Pentoxifylline : Not recommended for PAD treatment due to lack of efficacy.
  • • Option A. Pentoxifylline
  • • Option C. Stop canagliflozin : SGLT2 inhibitors should be used with caution in PAD but not discontinued unless there are specific complications.
  • • Option C. Stop canagliflozin
  • • Option D. Switching to a different antihypertensive : ACEi or ARBs can provide survival benefit in ASCVD but unlikely to significantly improve symptoms which is the priority in this case.
  • • Option D. Switching to a different antihypertensive

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is evaluated for right leg tiredness and cramping when walking 25 yards. His feet are shown following elevation (left) and during dependent positioning (right). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Diagnose peripheral artery disease.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with recurrent fevers, night sweats, weight loss, and a transient ischemic attack (TIA). ECG is normal and echo is shown in the video. CT head is normal as well. What is the most appropriate treatment?

options.label: C
options.text: Obtain blood cultures and begin empiric antibiotics

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. DOAC : Anticoagulation may be considered temporarily before surgery (or if the patient has atrial fibrillation) but is not definitive treatment in this patient.
  • • Option A. DOAC
  • • Option B. Thrombolytic therapy : Not indicated for TIA caused by a cardiac tumor.
  • • Option B. Thrombolytic therapy
  • • Option C. Blood cultures and antibiotics : Not appropriate for a cardiac myxoma.
  • • Option C. Blood cultures and antibiotics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Patients with a myxoma may present with valvular occlusive symptoms, such as dyspnea and syncope; embolic phenomena, including stroke or transient ischemic events; and/or constitutional symptoms, such as fever, anorexia, and weight loss.
  • ➤ In patients with atrial myxoma and a central nervous system embolic event, urgent cardiac surgical evaluation and excision are indicated.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with normal blood pressure and no significant medical history has a lipid profile showing total cholesterol of 241 mg/dL, HDL of 49 mg/dL, LDL of 116 mg/dL, and triglycerides of 128 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate next step?

options.label: B
options.text: Begin high-intensity statin therapy and ezetimibe

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Begin high-intensity statin therapy and Option B. Begin high-intensity statin therapy and ezetimibe : Starting statin therapy (with or without ezetimibe) is premature without assessing risk.
  • • Option A. Begin high-intensity statin therapy
  • • Option B. Begin high-intensity statin therapy and ezetimibe
  • • Option D. Repeat lipid profile while fasting : While fasting lipid profile is preferred, the non-fasting results do not warrant immediate repeat testing before risk assessment.
  • • Option D. Repeat lipid profile while fasting

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Cardiovascular risk scores can be used to assess a patient's future risk for major cardiovascular events and to identify preventive interventions.
  • ➤ The American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association Pooled Cohort Equations are commonly used to calculate the 10-year risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman undergoes successful primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) for an acute anterior STEMI and cardiogenic shock. Angiography reveals a 100% occlusion of mid LAD and a 70% stenosis of mid-right coronary artery (RCA). What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. PCI to LAD and RCA : While both lesions need to be addressed, the priority is to revascularize the culprit lesion (LAD) first to stabilize the patient.
  • • Option A. PCI to LAD and RCA
  • • Option C. PCI to RCA : The RCA is not the infarct-related artery and should not be prioritized over the LAD in this scenario.
  • • Option C. PCI to RCA
  • • Option D. Urgent CABG : CABG is an option for multivessel disease, but PCI of the culprit lesion is the immediate priority in a patient with cardiogenic shock.
  • • Option D. Urgent CABG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ In STEMI with cardiogenic shock, the immediate priority is to restore blood flow to the infarct-related artery with primary PCI. Non-culprit lesions can be addressed later in a staged procedure.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman 2 weeks postpartum presents with chest pain, ST-segment elevation in anterior leads, and elevated troponin. She has no risk factors for atherosclerosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Atherosclerotic plaque rupture : Unlikely in a young woman with no risk factors.
  • • Option A. Atherosclerotic plaque rupture
  • • Option B. Peripartum cardiomyopathy : Presents with heart failure symptoms and global LV dysfunction, not ST-elevation.
  • • Option B. Peripartum cardiomyopathy
  • • Option D. Takotsubo cardiomyopathy : Typically triggered by stress, often presents with apical ballooning on echo. Common in post-menopausal women (not young women).
  • • Option D. Takotsubo cardiomyopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Spontaneous coronary artery dissection is the most common cause of pregnancy-associated myocardial infarction and occurs most commonly in the first month postpartum

questions.text: A 73-year-old man presents with a 3-hour history of chest pain. His BP is 80/50 mmHg, HR is 120/min and has elevated JVP and clear lungs. ECG is shown. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Intra-aortic balloon pump : Indicated in cardiogenic shock with LV dysfunction, but not the first-line treatment for RV infarction.
  • • Option A. Intra-aortic balloon pump
  • • Option B. Intravenous dobutamine: Inotrope may be considered if fluids are ineffective, but not the initial management.
  • • Option B. Intravenous dobutamine:
  • • Option D. Oral metoprolol : Beta-blockers can worsen hypotension and should be avoided in RV infarction.
  • • Option D. Oral metoprolol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ A patient with an inferior myocardial infarction with right ventricular involvement and hypotension should receive intravenous fluids.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman 2 weeks postpartum presents with chest pain, ST-segment elevation in anterior leads, and elevated troponin. She has no risk factors for atherosclerosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Atherosclerotic plaque rupture : Unlikely in a young woman with no risk factors.
  • • Option A. Atherosclerotic plaque rupture
  • • Option B. Peripartum cardiomyopathy : Presents with heart failure symptoms and global LV dysfunction, not ST-elevation.
  • • Option B. Peripartum cardiomyopathy
  • • Option D. Takotsubo cardiomyopathy : Typically triggered by stress, often presents with apical ballooning on echo. Common in post menopausal women (not young women).
  • • Option D. Takotsubo cardiomyopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Spontaneous coronary artery dissection is the most common cause of pregnancy-associated myocardial infarction and occurs most commonly in the first month postpartum

questions.text: A 74-year-old man with a history of CABG presents with progressive fatigue, dyspnea, elevated jugular venous pressure with Kussmaul's sign, and a pericardial knock. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Cardiac tamponade : Would not present with Kussmaul's sign or pericardial knock.
  • • Option A. Cardiac tamponade
  • • Option B. Chronic liver disease : Can cause ascites and edema but not the other findings.
  • • Option B. Chronic liver disease
  • • Option D. Restrictive cardiomyopathy : Can mimic constrictive pericarditis, but the history of CABG makes the latter more likely.
  • • Option D. Restrictive cardiomyopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Kussmaul sign and pericardial knock, if present, are helpful clues to the presence of constrictive pericarditis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with an chest pain, nausea and diaphoresis. ECG is shown. The nearest tertiary care center is 140 minutes away. What is the most appropriate management?

options.label: B
options.text: Thrombolysis and admission to a telemetry bed

options.label: C
options.text: Thrombolysis and transfer to a PCI center

options.label: D
options.text: Transfer to a tertiary care center

questions.correct_answer: C. Thrombolysis and transfer to a PCI center
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. CT angiography : Delays reperfusion therapy, which is crucial in STEMI.
  • • Option A. CT angiography
  • • Option B. Thrombolyse and admit : Does not allow for timely angiography and potential rescue PCI.
  • • Option B. Thrombolyse and admit
  • • Option D. Transfer to tertiary care center : Delays reperfusion and worsens outcomes.
  • • Option D. Transfer to tertiary care center

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ For patients with STEMI, thrombolytic therapy is recommended if symptom onset is within 12 hours and PPCI is not available within 120 minutes of FMC.

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman presents with severe chest pain for the last 3 hours. She is diaphoretic and appears drowsy. Her BP is 80/60 mm Hg and PR is 60/min. ECG is shown below. She was started on aspirin, clopidogrel and heparin. What is the next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Atropine: Atropine may be useful for bradycardia but is unlikely to be effective in the setting of high-grade AV block. Additionally, it does not address the underlying myocardial ischemia.
  • • Option A. Atropine:
  • • Option B. Tenecteplase: While fibrinolysis with tenecteplase may be considered in some STEMI cases, it is not the first-line therapy in this case.
  • • Option B. Tenecteplase:
  • • Option C. Primary Angioplasty: Primary PCI is the preferred reperfusion strategy for STEMI, but it should be performed after stabilizing the patient's hemodynamics with temporary pacing.
  • • Option C. Primary Angioplasty:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Anterior MI related bradyarrhythmias are inherently unstable and need temporary pacing.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with subacute pericarditis, fever, pulsus paradoxus, and pericardial friction rub. ECG shows diffuse ST-segment elevation. Echocardiogram shows a small pericardial effusion. What is the most appropriate management?

options.label: C
options.text: Hospitalize and begin ibuprofen and colchicine

questions.correct_answer: C. Hospitalize and begin ibuprofen and colchicine
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Outpatient treatment : Not appropriate for high-risk pericarditis.
  • • Option A. Outpatient treatment
  • • Option B. Prednisone : Reserved for recurrent or refractory pericarditis.
  • • Option B. Prednisone
  • • Option D. Methylprednisolone : High-dose steroids are not first-line for initial treatment.
  • • Option D. Methylprednisolone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Hospitalize patients with acute pericarditis and high-risk features for initial treatment and monitoring.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman presents with cardiogenic shock. ECG showed ST depressions in multiple leads and her Troponins were elevated. PCI was performed successfully but she continues to be in cardiogenic shock and she is on aspirin, prasugrel and norepinephrine. Which of the following is the most appropriate additional management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Digoxin : Weak inotrope, unlikely to be effective in cardiogenic shock.
  • • Option A. Digoxin
  • • Option C. Metoprolol : Beta-blocker, contraindicated in cardiogenic shock due to negative inotropic effects.
  • • Option C. Metoprolol
  • • Option D. Urgent cardiac transplantation : Not feasible in the acute setting.
  • • Option D. Urgent cardiac transplantation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ IABP is a mechanical circulatory support device that can temporarily improve hemodynamics in patients with cardiogenic shock after MI by reducing afterload and improving coronary perfusion.

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman with COPD and prior stroke presents with intermittent chest pain. She is on aspirin, atorvastatin, MDI salbutamol and MDI tiotropium. ECG is taken and shown. Initial troponin is elevated and she was started on enoxaparin. What is the most appropriate additional treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Prasugrel : Absolutely C/I in patients with prior stroke and have to be carefully used in elderly patients who are aged > 75.
  • • Option B. Prasugrel
  • • Option C. Reteplase : Thrombolytic therapy, not indicated for NSTE-ACS.
  • • Option C. Reteplase
  • • Option D. Tirofiban : Gp IIb/IIIa inhibitor, typically used during PCI under special circumstances.
  • • Option D. Tirofiban

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ All patients with non–ST-elevation acute coronary syndrome should be treated with aspirin and a P2Y12 inhibitor regardless of reperfusion strategy.

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman with a history of NSTEMI and AF underwent a successful PCI with a drug eluting stent. What is the most appropriate management of her antithrombotic therapy?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Aspirin plus clopidogrel: This is traditional dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) and does not address the need for anticoagulation in AF.
  • • Option A. Aspirin plus clopidogrel:
  • • Option B. Aspirin plus ticagrelor: Similar to option a, it lacks anticoagulation for AF.
  • • Option B. Aspirin plus ticagrelor:
  • • Option C. Aspirin plus rivaroxaban plus ticagrelor: Triple therapy is no longer recommended as it increases bleeding risk without significant additional benefit compared to dual therapy.
  • • Option C. Aspirin plus rivaroxaban plus ticagrelor:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Among patients with atrial fibrillation who have undergone percutaneous coronary intervention for acute coronary syndrome, double therapy with clopidogrel or ticagrelor plus a direct oral anticoagulant is recommended over triple therapy with an oral anticoagulant, aspirin, and P2Y12 inhibitor to reduce the risk for bleeding.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman is evaluated for a 6-week history of persistent fatigue and occasional exertional dyspnea. ECG is shown. Which of the following abnormalities best describes the findings on this patient's ECG?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • This ECG shows a completed lateral myocardial infarction, with initial deep Q waves in leads I, aVL, and V6. There is also an inverted T wave in these leads.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true when comparing ST-segment elevation myocardial infarctions (STEMI) versus non–ST-segment elevation myocardial infarctions (NSTEMI)?
